title: EDLD 651 Final Presentation
text: Elyse Calhoun, Frances Pinkham, Yitong Jiang, Eunji Kong

title: EDLD Final Project v2
text:
Code
schooling <- import(here("data","Schooling.csv"))




Code
schoolingsub <- schooling %>%
  select(rownames,ed76, daded, momed, wage76, iqscore, age76, nearc2, nearc4)




Code
schoolingsub1 <- schoolingsub |> 
  mutate(near_college = ifelse(nearc2 == "yes" & nearc4 =="yes", "near_colleges", 
                               ifelse(nearc2 == "yes" & nearc4 =="no","near_cc", 
                                      ifelse(nearc2 == "no" & nearc4 =="yes","near_4yr", "not_near_college")))) 




Code
schoolingsub1 <- schoolingsub1 %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(daded,momed),
    names_to = "parent",
    values_to = "par_education")

schoolingsub1$parent <- gsub("daded", "dad", schoolingsub1$parent)

schoolingsub1$parent <- gsub("momed", "mom", schoolingsub1$parent)



Table 1: Demographics


Code
schoolingsub1 %>% 
    pivot_wider (names_from = parent,
                values_from = par_education) %>%
   select(-near_college) %>%
  gt_preview(schoolingsub1, top_n = 20, bottom_n = 1) %>%
  cols_label(ed76 = "Participant Education (Yrs)",
             wage76 = "Participant Wage (cents/hr)",
             iqscore = "IQ Score",
             age76 = "Age of Participant",
             nearc2 = "Near Community College",
             nearc4 = "Near Four-Year College",
             dad = "Paternal Education (Yrs)",
             mom = "Maternal Education (Yrs)",
             rownames = "Participant ID")

Research question 1: What is the relationship between parent education and participant’s education?


Plot 1


Code
schoolingsub1 |> 
  ggplot(aes(par_education, ed76, color = parent)) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, se = FALSE) + theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Relationship between Parent and Participant Education",
       subtitle = "From 1976 Survey",
       x = "Parental Education (yrs)",
       y = "Participant Education (yrs)",
       color = "Parent"
       )


`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'





Research question 2: What is the relationship between parent education and participant’s wage?


Plot 2


Code
schoolingsub1 |> 
  ggplot(aes(par_education, wage76, color = parent)) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, se = FALSE) + theme_minimal() +
   labs(title = "Relationship between Parent Education and Participant Wages",
       subtitle = "From 1976 Survey",
       x = "Parental Education (yrs)",
       y = "Participant Wages (cents/hr)",
       color = "Parent"
       )


`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'





Research question 3: Is there a difference in wage depending on whether you lived near a college?
<<<<<<< Updated upstream ### Table 2: Proximity and Wages ======= ### Table 1 >>>>>>> Stashed changes


Code
prox_wage <- schoolingsub1 %>%
  mutate(near_college = fct_recode(near_college, "Near 4-year College" ="near_4yr", 
                                   "Near Community College" = "near_cc",
                                   "Near 4-year and Community College" = "near_colleges",
                                   "Not Near College" = "not_near_college")) %>%
group_by(near_college) %>%
summarize(avg_wage = mean(wage76, na.rm = TRUE)/100) %>%
rename("Proximity to College" = near_college, "Participant Average Wage per Hour" = avg_wage) %>%

DT::datatable()




Results
Table 1 outlines our basic demographics for our study. For our participant demographics, we examined the education in years, IQ score, age, and proximity to higher education institutions. We also examined the level of maternal and paternal education level in years.
<<<<<<< Updated upstream Plot 1 reflects a linear regression model of participant education as a function of parental education. Although we have not performed a complete analysis on these descriptive statistics, our model may indicate a positive correlation between parental education and participant education. Both maternal and paternal education levels may be positively correlated with participant education levels.
Plot 2 also indicates a possible positive correlation between parental education and participant wages, shown in cents/hour. Further statistical testing would be required to verify this.
Table 2 displays the participant’s proximity to a college alongside their average wage per hour. Those participants who lived near both a four-year and a community college had the highest average wage per hour, at $6.45. According to the Department of Labor, the minimum wage in the USA in 1976 was $2.30 per hour, which means that these participants’ wages were 2.8043478 times higher than the minimum wage.
Those who resided near only a 4-year college had slightly lower average wages, at approximately $5.68/hr.


Those who were not near any college had marginally higher average wages ($5.18/hour) than those near a community college, at $5.13 per hour.
schoolingsub1 %>%
group_by(near_college) |> summarize(avg_wage = mean(wage76, na.rm = TRUE)/100) |> rename(“Proximity to College” = near_college, “Participant Average Wage per Hour” = avg_wage) %>% DT::datatable() ``` >>>>>>> Stashed changes

title: Reflection
text:
Elyse CalhounFrances PinkhamYitong JiangEunji Kong



Challenges faced

Understanding exactly what we were supposed to do for the Final Paper
Switching data sets during the Thanksgiving Break
Attempting to change variable names in a table
Trying to navigate R, github, and gitkraken in the correct order

Victories

Discovering that I messed up the qmd file trying to change variable names on a table, catching the mistake before pushing it back out to the group.
Teamwork makes the dream work.

Current Challenges

Gathering enough information to complete the final paper.





Challenges faced

Selecting a data set that was not excessively complicated but also not too clean
Gaining confidence in R syntax across multiple functions
Moving between Github, GitKraken, and RStudio

Victories

Managed to collaborate remotely!
Problem solved as a group
Able to diagnose problems more quickly

Current Challenges

Fluency in R language - I still have to review slides just about every time I work on an assignment to remember the proper syntax!





Challenges faced

Find a data set that we are familiar with the topic and are interested in exploring it.

Victories

Great communication in the team.
Everyone is willing to share the workloads.

Current Challenges

Create a figure for Research question 3: Is there a difference in wage depending on whether you lived near a college?





Challenges Faced

Working collaboratively on GitHub (confused with branches)

Victories

Working collaboratively on the analysis
Making website using Quarto (GitHub)

Current Challenges

Designing the website

title: The next R hurdle
text:
Add filter(), which is required for the final project.
Use fct_recode() to recode our variables, and work on other codes to make them more concise, if possible.
Explore potential relations among variables.

title: EDLD651 Final Paper
text:
Abstract
Environmental factors during childhood, such as parents’ educational level and proximity to a college or university, have been found to impact one’s income. Our current study aims to contribute to existing literature by examining this relationship. Results indicate that parental education is a significant predictor of participants’ education and wages. Additionally, living close to both a four-year university and a community college was correlated with the highest participant income. Examining these factors that impact income is important to understand how to promote equitable opportunity for everyone.


Introduction
Income level reflects the social and economic advancement in adulthood, and educational attainment has been found to have a direct impact on one’s occupation, income, and wealth.Education is a critical element in the development of individuals and societies, providing a foundation for lifelong learning, personal growth, and social mobility. Among multiple factors that could influence an individual’s educational achievements, parental education has received much attention. Researchers argue that parents’ education may influence parents’ skills, values and knowledge of the educational system; which, in turn, may influence their educational practices at home and the skills children have as models, as well as the parents’ ability to intervene in the educational system on their children’s behalf (Eccles 2005). Parents with more education also have higher expectations for their children’s education, which, in turn, predicts great educational attainment for their children, even until adulthood (Alexander, Entwisle, and Bedinger 1994). Research has shown that young adults whose parents have attained no more than a high school diploma are less likely to aspire to a bachelor’s degree and less likely to be college qualified (Berkner and Chavez 1997; Horn and Nuñez 2000).
Examining predictors and correlates of adult financial well-being and earnings as they relate to one’s upbringing, there are established findings on the links between family background and later occupational outcomes (Deary et al. 2005; Schoon 2010). Given that family economic status is related to the neighborhood that one may live in growing up, one factor that may impact future education attainment may be whether you grew up near a college or university. Card (1995) suggests that growing up in an area near or around a college potentially has a direct effect on wage earnings. The assumption is made that people earn higher wages based on the amount of schooling they have completed (Dearden, Ferri, and Meghir, n.d.). Limited research showed that community of residence (e.g., residence in rural or urban areas, residence near a private or public college) significantly influenced the developments of both males and females’ social and economic standing, including their educational achievements, employment and incomes (Sewell et al. 2003). However, more studies are needed to explore the effects of family background, later educational and occupational outcomes on adult earning ability (Furnham and Cheng 2013).
The purpose of this study is to understand the relationship between parents’ education, geographic locations (i.e., proximity to college), and participants’ education and income. Specifically, given the relationships among these factors in previous literature, we sought to answer:

What is the relationship between parent education and participant’s education?
What is the relationship between parent education and participant’s wage?
Is there a difference in wage depending on whether you lived near a college?




Table 1: Demograpnics

Method
The current study is a secondary data analysis from the National Longitudinal Survey of Young Men (NLSYM), which started in 1966 with 5525 young men between the ages of 14 and 24 in the United States. The current study looks at a subset of this data collected in 1976.

Participants
4122 young men were included in this study. Table 1 provides demographic data of our sample. The average age of our participants in 1976 were 28.38 (SD = 3) with an average of 13.92 years of education (SD = 2.27). The average education of the parents of the participants were 10.63 years of education (SD = 2.92). Interestingly, during a time when education disparity between gender was large, paternal (M = NA, SD = NA) and maternal education (M = NA, SD = NA) was similar in our sample.
As is true for many longitudinal studies in the mid-1960s (Card 1995), our data is not a random, representative sample of the United States population. Data was collected from neighborhoods with a high concentration of non-White residents. In the 1960s, black represented 10% of the US population (Scammon 1961); however, in our study, 19.73% of our sample were black.


Measures
In this study, we examined participants’ responses to question regarding their age, ethnicity, IQ score, parent’s education (both maternal and paternal), current level of participant education, participant’s current wage, and proximity to college. The age variable is a continuous variable measured in number of years (range = 24- 34), and the ethnicity is a binary categorical variable in which participants were asked whether they identify as black. The IQ score variable is a continuous variable (range = 50- 149). Participant and parental education were asked in number of years (continuous variable). Participant current wage was asked as cents earned per hour (range = 112- 2404). Lastly, participants were asked whether they live near a 4-year college, community college, both, or neither.


Statistical Analyses
There were no missing data in our variables, except for in the IQ scores. We compared the means and standard deviation of the data including and excluding participants with missing data and found minimal difference. Therefore, for the purpose of this study (to use the filter() function), missing data was exluded from our analysis. To answer our first research question (e.g., What is the relationship between parent education and participant’s education?), we created General Linear Model and plotted the relationship between parent and participant’s education and displayed the fitted linear line. To answer our second research question (e.g., What is the relationship between parent education and participant’s wage?), we created General Linear Model and plotted the relationship between parent’s education and participant’s education and displayed the fitted linear line. Lastly, to answer our third research question (e.g., Is there a difference in wage depending on whether you lived near a college?), we created the ANOVA model and calculated participant’s wage based on their response to living proximity to college and plotted the information as a violin graph.



Results


Table 2. Model of the relationship between parents' education and participants' education



Model




(Intercept)
4.352***



[3.834, 4.869]


Participants' education
0.451***



[0.414, 0.488]


Num.Obs.
4122


R2
0.124



 + p < 0.1, * p < 0.05, ** p < 0.01, *** p < 0.001













Figure 1 reflects a linear regression model of participant education as a function of parental education. Regardless of parental education, paternal and maternal education, both, was associated with higher educational attainment for the participants. Based on the results in Table 2, on average, in the population, one unit change in parent’s education is related to 0.451 more years in participant’s education, indicating a positive correlation between parental education and participant education.


Table 3. Model of the relationship between parents' education and participants' wages



Model




(Intercept)
9.853***



[9.628, 10.077]


Participants' wages
0.001***



[0.001, 0.002]


Num.Obs.
4122


R2
0.013



 + p < 0.1, * p < 0.05, ** p < 0.01, *** p < 0.001













Figure 2 also indicates a positive correlation between parental education and participant wages, shown in cents/hour. When parental education is shorter than around 12.5 years, with longer education of fathers, participants have higher wages. However, when parental education is longer than around 12.5 years, with a longer maternal education, participants achieve a higher level in wages. Table 3 shows us that, on average in the population, one unit change in parental education is positively related to 0.001 more cents per hour in participant’s wages. Although it is statistically significant, considering small coefficient, it may not be an artifact of the large sample size.


Table 4. Average participant wage based on proximity to college


Proximity to College
Participant Average Wage per Hour




Near 4-year College
6.003385


Near 4-year and Community College
6.663877


Near Community College
5.855421


Not Near College
5.583990






Table 4 displays the participant’s proximity to a college alongside their average wage per hour. Those participants who lived near both a four-year and a community college had the highest average wage per hour, at $6.45. According to the (Unknown 2002), the minimum wage in the USA in 1976 was $2.3 per hour, which means that these participants’ wages were NNN? times higher than the minimum wage. Those who resided near only a 4-year college had slightly lower average wages, at approximately $5.68/hr. Those who were not near any college had marginally higher average wages ($5.18/hour) than those near a community college, at $5.13 per hour.





Using ANOVA analysis, we found that there is a statistically significant (p <0.001) relationship between the proximity to college and participant wages. In Figure 3, we highlight that there is a meaningful variation in average participant wages both within and between participant’s proximity to a college. Specifically, participants who live near four year and community colleges make higher wages (Mean = 666.39), on average, than other groups. There is substantial variability within each group of proximity to college, with standard deviations in variable participant’s wage (wage76) between 213.14 and 300.25.


Discussion
Family background is believed to have vital influence on individuals’ developments. The current study intended to explain factors that impact young adults’ education length and wages. Our research interest lies in whether young adults from family with longer parental educations and closer residence to college would have different length of education experience and incomes. We chose four factors for discussion, which are parental education, proximity to college, participant education and participant wage.
We created several linear models and tested critical assumptions. After analysis, we found that, on average in the population, a longer parental education is related to longer participant education, and is associated with higher participant wages. Besides, participants who resided near four year and community colleges earn higher wages. Results of both existing studies and research summarized in this paper document the link between family background and offspring’s achievements. We have shown the positive relations of parents’ education as well as family residence (i.e., proximity to the college) to their offspring’s academic and economic achievements. Findings of this study align with those of previous research (e.g., Eccles (2005); Tuijnman, Chinapah, and Fägerlind (1988)).
Yet, there are limitations in our study. We still need to do further explorations and consider more about personal factors and their effects on individuals’ academic and economic gains, such as genders, races, and IQ scores. Also, there is space to analyze the potential covariates among these relations. But still, our study provides a basis for future researchers to examine the impact of family factors and individual developments.








Reference

Alexander, Karl L, Doris R Entwisle, and Samuel D Bedinger. 1994. “When Expectations Work: Race and Socioeconomic Differences in School Performance.” Social Psychology Quarterly, 283–99.


Berkner, Lutz, and Lisa Chavez. 1997. Access to Postsecondary Education for the 1992 High School Graduates. Postsecondary Education Descriptive Analysis Reports. Statistical Analysis Report. ERIC.


Card, David. 1995. “Using Geographic Variation in College Proximity to Estimate the Return to Schooling, Aspects of Labour Market Behaviour: Essays in Honour of John Vanderkamp. Ed.” LN Christofides, EK Grant, and R. Swidinsky.


Dearden, Lorraine, Javier Ferri, and Costas Meghir. n.d. “THE EFFECT OF SCHOOL QUALITY ON EDUCATIONAL ATTAINMENT AND WAGES.” THE REVIEW OF ECONOMICS AND STATISTICS.


Deary, Ian J, Michelle D Taylor, Carole L Hart, Valerie Wilson, George Davey Smith, David Blane, and John M Starr. 2005. “Intergenerational Social Mobility and Mid-Life Status Attainment: Influences of Childhood Intelligence, Childhood Social Factors, and Education.” Intelligence 33 (5): 455–72.


Eccles, Jacquelynne S. 2005. “Influences of Parents’ Education on Their Children’s Educational Attainments: The Role of Parent and Child Perceptions.” London Review of Education.


Furnham, Adrian, and Helen Cheng. 2013. “Factors Influencing Adult Earnings: Findings from a Nationally Representative Sample.” The Journal of Socio-Economics 44: 120–25.


Horn, Laura, and Anne-Marie Nuñez. 2000. Mapping the Road to College First-Generation Students’ Math Track, Planning Strategies, and Context of Support. Diane Publishing.


Scammon, Richard. 1961. “1960 Census of the Population: Supplementary Reports: Race of the Population of the United States, by States: 1960.” US Department of Commerce.


Schoon, Ingrid. 2010. “Childhood Cognitive Ability and Adult Academic Attainment: Evidence from Three British Cohort Studies.” Longitudinal and Life Course Studies 1 (3): 241–158.


Sewell, William H, Robert M Hauser, Kristen W Springer, and Taissa S Hauser. 2003. “As We Age: A Review of the Wisconsin Longitudinal Study, 1957–2001.” Research in Social Stratification and Mobility 20: 3–111.


Tuijnman, Albert, Vinayagum Chinapah, and Ingemar Fägerlind. 1988. “Adult Education and Earnings: A 45-Year Longitudinal Study of 834 Swedish Men.” Economics of Education Review 7 (4): 423–37.


Unknown. 2002. “History of Changes to the Minimum Wage Law.” US Department of Labor.

title: paper
text:
Introduction
When discussing minimum wages and its economic impact, most research focuses on the impact of employment (Neumark and Wascher 2003). Card (1995) suggests that growing up in an area near or around a college potentially has a direct effect on wage earnings. The assumption is made that people earn higher wages based on the amount of schooling they have completed (Dearden, Ferri, and Meghir, n.d.). For this study, we want to determine if college proximity and the education level of parents have an impact on wage earnings.
The purpose of this study is to understand the relationship between parents’ education, geographic locations (i.e., proximity to college), and participants’ education and income. Specifically, given the relationships among these factors in previous literature, we sought to answer:

What is the relationship between parent education and participant’s education?
What is the relationship between parent education and participant’s wage?
Is there a difference in wage depending on whether you lived near a college?

Method
The current study is a secondary data analysis from the National Longitudinal Survey of Young Men (NLSYM), which started in 1966 with 5525 young men between the ages of 14 and 24 in the United States. The current study looks at a subset of this data collected in 1976.

Participants
3010 young men were included in this study. Table 1 provides demographic data of our sample. The average age of our participants in 1976 were 28.12 (SD = 3.14) with an average of 13.26 years of education (SD = 2.68). The average education of the parents of the participants were 10.16 years of education (SD = 3.13). Interestingly, during a time when education disparity between gender was large, paternal (M = 3.27, SD = 3.27) and maternal education (M = 2.99, SD = 2.99) was similar in our sample.
As is true for many longitudinal studies in the mid-1960s (Card 1995), our data is not a random, representative sample of the United States population. Data was collected from neighborhoods with a high concentration of non-White residents. In the 1960s, black represented 10% of the US population (Scammon 1961); however, in our study, 23.36% of our sample were black.


Measures
In this study, we examined participants’ responses to question regarding their age, ethnicity, IQ score, parent’s education (both maternal and paternal), current level of participant education, participant’s current wage, and proximity to college. The age variable is a continuous variable measured in number of years (range = 24- 34), and the ethnicity is a binary categorical variable in which participants were asked whether they identify as black. The IQ score variable is a continuous variable (range = NA- NA). Participant and parental education were asked in number of years (continuous variable). Participant current wage was asked as cents earned per hour (range = 100- 2404). Lastly, participants were asked whether they live near a 4-year college, community college, both, or neither.


Statistical Analyses
There were no missing data in our variables, except for in the IQ scores. However, since IQ scores were included to provide demographic information, there were no need to impute data for missing data. To answer our first research question (e.g., What is the relationship between parent education and participant’s education?) descriptively, we plotted the relationship between parent and participant’s education and displayed the fitted linear line. To answer our second research question (e.g., What is the relationship between parent education and participant’s wage?) descriptively, we plotted the relationship between parent’s education and participant’s education and displayed the fitted linear line. Lastly, to answer our third research question (e.g., Is there a difference in wage depending on whether you lived near a college?) descriptively, we calculated participant’s wage based on their response to living proximity to college and plotted the information as a violin graph.



Results





Figure 1 reflects a linear regression model of participant education as a function of parental education. Although we have not performed a complete analysis on these descriptive statistics, our model may indicate a positive correlation between parental education and participant education.





Figure 2 also indicates a possible positive correlation between parental education and participant wages, shown in cents/hour. Further statistical testing would be required to verify this.
Those who resided near only a 4-year college had slightly lower average wages, at approximately $5.68/hr. Those who were not near any college had marginally higher average wages ($5.18/hour) than those near a community college, at $5.13 per hour.

Dearden, Lorraine, Javier Ferri, and Costas Meghir. n.d. “THE EFFECT OF SCHOOL QUALITY ON EDUCATIONAL ATTAINMENT AND WAGES.” THE REVIEW OF ECONOMICS AND STATISTICS.


Neumark, David, and William Wascher. 2003. “Minimum Wages and Skill Acquisition: Another Look at Schooling Effects.” Economics of Education Review 22 (1): 1–10. https://doi.org/https://doi.org/10.1016/S0272-7757(02)00006-7.


Scammon, Richard. 1961. “1960 Census of the Population: Supplementary Reports: Race of the Population of the United States, by States: 1960.” US Department of Commerce.
